            <div>
               <h2 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions" class="toc2 head">local-definitions</h2>Local DefinitionsAllows components, and inventory-items to be defined within the POA&amp;M
               for circumstances where no OSCAL-based SSP exists, or is not delivered with the POA&amp;M.
               <p>An array of Component objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Component</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>components</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A defined component that can be part of an implemented system.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks in-use">
                        <p class="nb">(In use)</p>
                        <p>Used to add any components, not defined via the System Security Plan (AR-&gt;AP-&gt;SSP)</p>
                     </div>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Components may be products, services, application programming interface (APIs), policies,
                           processes, plans, guidance, standards, or other tangible items that enable security
                           and/or privacy.</p>
                        <p>The <code>type</code> indicates which of these component types is represented.</p>
                        <p>When defining a <code>service</code> component where are relationship to other components is known, one or more <code>link</code> entries with rel values of provided-by and used-by can be used to link to the specific
                           component identifier(s) that provide and use the service respectively.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <p>An array of Inventory Item objects</p>
               <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">object Inventory Item</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An object  member of array <code>inventory-items</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/inventory-items</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A single managed inventory item within the system.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks in-use">
                        <p class="nb">(In use)</p>
                        <p>Used to add any inventory-items, not defined via the System Security Plan (AR-&gt;AP-&gt;SSP)</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>RemarksAdditional commentary on the containing object.

               uuid.

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>
                     <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>

                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components/props/ns">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

                        <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components/props/class</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's <code>name</code>. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of
                        multiple properties of the same object with the same <code>name</code> and <code>ns</code>. </p>

                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                                 a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                              <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/link"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

               <div class="obj-desc">

                  </div>
               </div>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components/links/href" class="toc5 head">href</h5>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                        can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                        a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                        which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                        of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                        of the document containing the link.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components/links/href">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components/links/href</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Hypertext Reference</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components/links/href</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>

                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components/responsible-roles/props/ns" class="toc6 head">ns</h6>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                           organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                           to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                           can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                           This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                           an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                           control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                           uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                           be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                           by the associated OSCAL model.

                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">

                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered

                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">

                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/inventory-items/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/inventory-item/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                        <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/inventory-items/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                        <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/inventory-items/links/href" class="toc5 head">href</h5>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                        can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/inventory-items/implemented-components/props" class="toc5 head">props</h5>
                        <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/inventory-items/implemented-components/props</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/inventory-item/implemented-component/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/inventory-items/implemented-components/props">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/inventory-items/implemented-components/props</a> in the object map.</p>

                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/inventory-items/implemented-components/props/ns" class="toc6 head">ns</h6>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                           organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                           to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                           can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                           This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                           an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                           control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                           uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                           be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                           by the associated OSCAL model.
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/inventory-item/implemented-component/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                 to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                              <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment

                              organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means

                              an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                              control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                              uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                              be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined

                              <div class="remarks">

                     <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                        qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                        may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                              OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                              or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                              and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                              an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                              lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                              consistency.</p>
                           <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                              was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                              of the containing object.</p>

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/props/ns" class="toc4 head">ns</h4>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                     organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                     to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                     can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                     This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                     an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                     control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                     uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                     be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                     by the associated OSCAL model.
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/props/ns">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/props/ns</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                     associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                           names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                           with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                        <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                           to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                        <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
            </section>

                  <p class="description">A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's <code>name</code>. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of

                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                              a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                           <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                        </div>
                     </details>

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/links/href" class="toc4 head">href</h4>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                     can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                     that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                     a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                     which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                     that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                     is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                     of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                     of the document containing the link.
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/links/href">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/links/href</a> in the object map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">string Hypertext Reference</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                     <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/links/href</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                           that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                        <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                           "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                        <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                           resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                           containing the link.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
            </section>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/actors/props" class="toc5 head">props</h5>
                        <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/actors/props</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/origin/actor/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/actors/props">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/actors/props</a> in the object map.</p>

                  </section>
                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/actors/props/ns" class="toc6 head">ns</h6>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                           organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                           to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                           can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                           This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                           an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                           control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                           uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                           be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                           by the associated OSCAL model.
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/origin/actor/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                        </div>
                     </div>

                           <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/actors/props/ns</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                 to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>

                           <h6 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/actors/links/href" class="toc6 head">href</h6>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                           can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                           that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                           a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier

                           that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource

                           of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                           of the document containing the link.

                              <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment

                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>

                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">

                           <h6 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/related-tasks/props/ns" class="toc6 head">ns</h6>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                           organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                           to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                           can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                           This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                           an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                           control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                           uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                           be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                           by the associated OSCAL model.

                        <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered

                  <section class="json-obj">

                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/related-tasks/subjects/props" class="toc6 head">props</h6>

                              </div>
                              <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                                 qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                                 may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                              <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                       OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                       or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                       and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                       an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                       lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                       consistency.</p>
                                    <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                       was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                       of the containing object.</p>
                                 </div>
                              </details>
                           </div>

                     <section class="json-obj">
                        <div class="header">
                           <div>
                              <h7 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/related-tasks/subjects/props/ns" class="toc7 head">ns</h7>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                              organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                              to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                              can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                              This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                              an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                              control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                              uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                              be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                              by the associated OSCAL model.

                           </div>

                              associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                    names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                    with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                                 <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                    to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                                 <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                                 </div>
                                 <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                                    qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                                    may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                                 <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                    <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                    <div class="remarks">
                                       <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within

                                          or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                          and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                          an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                          lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                          consistency.</p>
                                       <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                          was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                          of the containing object.</p>

                                 organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                                 to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                                 can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                                 This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                                 an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                                 control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                                 uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                                 be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                                 by the associated OSCAL model.

                                    <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed

                                 <h8 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/related-tasks/subjects/include-subjects/links/href" class="toc8 head">href</h8>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                                 can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                 that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                                 a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                                 which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                                 that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                                 is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                                 of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                                 of the document containing the link.

                              <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                              <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                       that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                                    <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                       "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                                    <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                       resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                                       containing the link.</p>

                              </details>

                        <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject" class="toc5 head">identified-subject</h5>Identified SubjectUsed to detail assessment subjects that were identfied by this task.Assessment
                        Subject Placeholder Universally Unique Identifier ReferenceReferences a unique assessment
                        subject placeholder defined by this task.
                        <p>An array of Subject of Assessment objects</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">object Subject of Assessment</p>

                              <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">Identifies system elements being assessed, such as components, inventory items, and
                              locations. In the assessment plan, this identifies a planned assessment subject. In
                              the assessment results this is an actual assessment subject, and reflects any changes
                              from the plan. exactly what will be the focus of this assessment. Any subjects not
                              identified in this way are out-of-scope.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks in-use">
                                 <p class="nb">(In use)</p>
                                 <p>The assessment subjects that the task identified, which will be used by another task
                                    through a subject-placeholder reference. Such a task will "consume" these subjects.</p>
                              </div>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Processing of an include/exclude pair starts with processing the include, then removing
                                    matching entries in the exclude.</p>
                              </div>

                              </div>
                              <p class="description">Identifies system elements being assessed, such as components, inventory items, and
                                 locations. In the assessment plan, this identifies a planned assessment subject. In
                                 the assessment results this is an actual assessment subject, and reflects any changes
                                 from the plan. exactly what will be the focus of this assessment. Any subjects not
                                 identified in this way are out-of-scope.</p>
                              <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks in-use">
                                    <p class="nb">(In use)</p>
                                    <p>The assessment subjects that the task identified, which will be used by another task
                                       through a subject-placeholder reference. Such a task will "consume" these subjects.</p>
                                 </div>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>Processing of an include/exclude pair starts with processing the include, then removing
                                       matching entries in the exclude.</p>

                              The referenced assessment subject is a component defined in the SSP, or in the local-definitions

                                          and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate

                                 organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means

                                 <div class="obj-desc">

                                       <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/include-subjects/props</p>
                                    </div>
                                    <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                                       qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                                       may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                                    <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                       <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                       <div class="remarks">
                                          <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                             OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                             or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                             and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                             an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                             lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                             consistency.</p>
                                          <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                             was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                             of the containing object.</p>
                                       </div>
                                    </details>
                                 </div>

                           </div>
                           <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/include-subjects/props">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/include-subjects/props</a> in the object map.</p>

                                    organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                                    to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                                    can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                                    This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                                    an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                                    control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                                    uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                                    be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                                    by the associated OSCAL model.
                                    <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/origin/related-task/identified-subject/subject/include-subject/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                                 </div>
                                 <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                                    associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                                 <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                    <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                    <div class="remarks">
                                       <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                          names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                          with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                                       <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                          to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                                       <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                                    can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                    that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                                    a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                                    which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                                    that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                                    is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                                    of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                                    of the document containing the link.

                                 <details open="open" class="remarks-group">

                                       <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment

                                 <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                                 <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                                 <div class="obj-desc">
                                    <div class="obj-matrix">
                                       <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                                       <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                                       <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                                       <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/exclude-subjects/props</p>
                                    </div>
                                    <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                                       qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                                       may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                                    <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                       <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                       <div class="remarks">
                                          <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                             OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                             or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                             and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                             an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                             lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                             consistency.</p>
                                          <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                             was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                             of the containing object.</p>
                                       </div>
                                    </details>
                                 </div>

                                    organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                                    to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                                    can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                                    This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                                    an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                                    control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                                    uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                                    be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                                    by the associated OSCAL model.

                                    <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                                    <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                                    <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                                    <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/exclude-subjects/props/ns</p>
                                 </div>
                                 <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                                    associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                                 <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                    <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                    <div class="remarks">
                                       <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                          names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                          with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                                       <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                          to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                                       <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                                    </div>
                                 </details>
                              </div>

                                    <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                       <summary>Remarks</summary>

                                          <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to

                                 <div>
                                    <h9 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/exclude-subjects/links/href" class="toc9 head">href</h9>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                                    can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                    that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                                    a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                                    which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                                    that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                                    is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                                    of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                                    of the document containing the link.
                                    <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/origin/related-task/identified-subject/subject/exclude-subject/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                              <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/exclude-subjects/links/href">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/exclude-subjects/links/href</a> in the object map.</p>
                              <div class="obj-desc">
