                                    <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                                    <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/exclude-subjects/links/href</p>
                                 </div>
                                 <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                                 <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                    <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                    <div class="remarks">
                                       <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                          that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                                       <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                          "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                                       <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                          resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                                          containing the link.</p>
                                    </div>
                                 </details>
                              </div>

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>
                     <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/subject/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props</a> in the object map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">array </p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>An array  with key <code>props</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props</p>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/name" class="toc5 head">name</h5>Property NameA textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic,
                        or quality of the property's containing object.
                        
                        A label or descriptor that is tied to a sensitivity or classification marking system.
                        An optional class can be used to define the specific marking system used for the associated
                        value.
                        
                        
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/subject/prop/@name"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/name">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/name</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Name</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a> with key <code>name</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/name</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or
                        quality of the property's containing object.</p>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/uuid" class="toc5 head">uuid</h5>Property Universally Unique IdentifierA unique identifier that can be used to reference
                        this property elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistently used for
                        a given location across revisions of the document.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/subject/prop/@uuid"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/uuid">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/uuid</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Universally Unique Identifier</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uuid">uuid</a> with key <code>uuid</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/uuid</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                        document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                        of the document.</p>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/subject/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/ns">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>

                     </div>

                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/value">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/value</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">

                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.string">string</a> with key <code>value</code>.</p>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/class" class="toc5 head">class</h5>Property ClassA textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the
                        property's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the
                        semantics of multiple properties of the same object with the same name and ns. A class
                        can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of a
                        specific class value.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/subject/prop/@class"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/class">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/class</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Class</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a> with key <code>class</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/props/class</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's <code>name</code>. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of
                        multiple properties of the same object with the same <code>name</code> and <code>ns</code>. </p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>A <code>class</code> can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/links" class="toc4 head">links</h4>

                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Link</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>links</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/links</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                                 a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                              <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/subject/link"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">array </p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>An array  with key <code>links</code>.</p>

                  </div>
               </div>
               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/links/href" class="toc5 head">href</h5>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                        can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                        that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                        a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                        which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                        that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                        is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                        of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                        of the document containing the link.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/subject/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/links/href">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/links/href</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Hypertext Reference</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/subjects/links/href</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

                     <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/relevant-evidence/href" class="toc4 head">href</h4>Relevant Evidence Reference&gt;A resolvable URL reference to relevant evidence.The value

                     #fragment that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference
                     using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an
                     identifier which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or
                     another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet
                     resource is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the
                     location of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the
                     location of the document containing the link.

                     <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/relevant-evidence/href</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">&gt;A resolvable URL reference to relevant evidence.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                           that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                        <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                           "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is <a>within the scope of the containing OSCAL document</a>.</p>
                        <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/relevant-evidence/props" class="toc4 head">props</h4>
                     <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                           <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/relevant-evidence/props</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/relevant-evidence/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/relevant-evidence/props">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/relevant-evidence/props</a> in the object map.</p>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/relevant-evidence/props/ns" class="toc5 head">ns</h5>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                        organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                        to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                        can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                        This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                        an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                        control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                        uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                        be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                        by the associated OSCAL model.
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/relevant-evidence/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/relevant-evidence/props/ns">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/relevant-evidence/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/relevant-evidence/props/ns</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>

         <section class="json-obj">
            <div class="header">
               <div>
                  <h3 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/props" class="toc3 head">props</h3>
                  <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                        <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                        <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/props</p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                        qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                        may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                              OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                              or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                              and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                              an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                              lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                              consistency.</p>
                           <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                              was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                              of the containing object.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risk/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
               </div>
            </div>

               </div>
            </section>
            <section class="json-obj">
               <div class="header">
                  <div>
                     <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/props/ns" class="toc4 head">ns</h4>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                     organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                     to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                     can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                     This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                     an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                     control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                     uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                     be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                     by the associated OSCAL model.
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risk/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/props/ns">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/props/ns</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                     associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                           names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                           with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                        <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                           to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                        <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>

                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's <code>name</code>. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of
                     multiple properties of the same object with the same <code>name</code> and <code>ns</code>. </p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">

                     <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/links/href" class="toc4 head">href</h4>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                     can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                     that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                     a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                     which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                     that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                     is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                     of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                     of the document containing the link.
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risk/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/links/href">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/links/href</a> in the object map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">string Hypertext Reference</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                     <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                     <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/links/href</p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                           that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                        <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                           "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                        <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                           resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                           containing the link.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
            </section>

               <section class="json-obj">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div>
                        <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/actors/props" class="toc5 head">props</h5>
                        <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/actors/props</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risk/origin/actor/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                     </div>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/actors/props">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/actors/props</a> in the object map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">

                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">string Property Name</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                           <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a> with key <code>name</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/actors/props/name</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or
                           quality of the property's containing object.</p>
                     </div>
                  </section>
                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/actors/props/uuid" class="toc6 head">uuid</h6>Property Universally Unique IdentifierA unique identifier that can be used to reference
                           this property elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistently used for
                           a given location across revisions of the document.
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risk/origin/actor/prop/@uuid"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                        </div>
                     </div>
                     <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/actors/props/uuid">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/actors/props/uuid</a> in the object map.</p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">

                           <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uuid">uuid</a> with key <code>uuid</code>.</p>

                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                           document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                           of the document.</p>
                     </div>
                  </section>
                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/actors/props/ns" class="toc6 head">ns</h6>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                           organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                           to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                           can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                           This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                           an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                           control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                           uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                           be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                           by the associated OSCAL model.
                           <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risk/origin/actor/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                        </div>
                     </div>
                     <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/actors/props/ns">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/actors/props/ns</a> in the object map.</p>
                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                           <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                           <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/actors/props/ns</p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                           associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                 to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                  </section>

                  <section class="json-obj">
                     <div class="header">
                        <div>
                           <h6 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/actors/props/class" class="toc6 head">class</h6>Property ClassA textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the
                           property's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the
                           semantics of multiple properties of the same object with the same name and ns. A class
                           can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of a
                           specific class value.

                           that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using

               <section class="json-obj">

                        <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/props" class="toc5 head">props</h5>

                        <div class="obj-desc">
                           <div class="obj-matrix">
                              <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                              <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                              <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                              <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/props</p>
                           </div>
                           <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                              qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                              may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks">
                                 <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                    OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                    or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                    and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                    an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                    lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                    consistency.</p>
                                 <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                    was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                    of the containing object.</p>
                              </div>
                           </details>
                        </div>
                        <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risk/origin/related-task/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                           <h6 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/props/ns" class="toc6 head">ns</h6>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                           organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                           to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                           can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                           This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                           an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                           control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                           uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                           be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                           by the associated OSCAL model.

                        <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to

                              <h7 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/responsible-parties/props/ns" class="toc7 head">ns</h7>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                              organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                              to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                              can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.

                              an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                              control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                              uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                              be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                              by the associated OSCAL model.

                              <h7 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/subjects/props/ns" class="toc7 head">ns</h7>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                              organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                              to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                              can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                              This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                              an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                              control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                              uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                              be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                              by the associated OSCAL model.

                     <section class="json-obj">

                           <div>

                              <div class="obj-desc">
                                 <div class="obj-matrix">
                                    <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                                    <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                                    <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                                    <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/subjects/include-subjects/props</p>
                                 </div>
                                 <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                                    qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                                    may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                                 <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                    <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                    <div class="remarks">
                                       <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                          OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                          or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                          and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                          an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                          lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                          consistency.</p>
                                       <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                          was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                          of the containing object.</p>
                                    </div>
                                 </details>
                              </div>

                           </div>
                        </div>
                        <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/subjects/include-subjects/props">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/subjects/include-subjects/props</a> in the object map.</p>
                        <div class="obj-desc">

                        <section class="json-obj">

                              <div>
                                 <h8 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/subjects/include-subjects/props/ns" class="toc8 head">ns</h8>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                                 organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                                 to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                                 can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                                 This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                                 an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                                 control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                                 uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                                 be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                                 by the associated OSCAL model.
                                 <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risk/origin/related-task/subject/include-subject/prop/@ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>

                              </div>
                              <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                                 associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                              <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                       names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                       with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                                    <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                       to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                                    <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

                                 can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                 that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                                 a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                                 which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                                 that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource

                                          and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                          an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                          lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                          consistency.</p>

                                 organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                                 to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                                 can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.

                                 an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                                 control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered

                        <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject" class="toc5 head">identified-subject</h5>Identified SubjectUsed to detail assessment subjects that were identfied by this task.Assessment
                        Subject Placeholder Universally Unique Identifier ReferenceReferences a unique assessment
                        subject placeholder defined by this task.

                           </div>
                           <p class="description">Identifies system elements being assessed, such as components, inventory items, and
                              locations. In the assessment plan, this identifies a planned assessment subject. In
                              the assessment results this is an actual assessment subject, and reflects any changes
                              from the plan. exactly what will be the focus of this assessment. Any subjects not
                              identified in this way are out-of-scope.</p>
                           <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                              <summary>Remarks</summary>
                              <div class="remarks in-use">
                                 <p class="nb">(In use)</p>
                                 <p>The assessment subjects that the task identified, which will be used by another task
                                    through a subject-placeholder reference. Such a task will "consume" these subjects.</p>
                              </div>

                                    matching entries in the exclude.</p>

                                 <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace

                                 <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                    <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                    <div class="remarks">
                                       <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                          OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                          or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                          and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                          an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                          lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                          consistency.</p>
                                       <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value

                                 organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means

                                 <p class="obj-name">string Property Namespace</p>
                                 <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                                 <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a> with key <code>ns</code>.</p>
                                 <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/props/ns</p>
                              </div>
                              <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                                 associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                              <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                       names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                       with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                                    <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                       to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                                    <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                                 </div>
                              </details>
                           </div>
                        </section>

                        <section class="json-obj">
                           <div class="header">
                              <div>
                                 <h8 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/links/href" class="toc8 head">href</h8>Hypertext ReferenceA resolvable URL reference to a resource.The value of the href
                                 can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                 that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.If a local reference using
                                 a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier
                                 which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object
                                 that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.If an internet resource
                                 is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location
                                 of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location
                                 of the document containing the link.
                                 <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risk/origin/related-task/identified-subject/subject/link/@href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                              </div>
                           </div>
                           <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/links/href">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/links/href</a> in the object map.</p>
                           <div class="obj-desc">
                              <div class="obj-matrix">
                                 <p class="obj-name">string Hypertext Reference</p>
                                 <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                                 <p>A string of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a> with key <code>href</code>.</p>
                                 <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/links/href</p>
                              </div>
                              <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                              <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                 <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                 <div class="remarks">
                                    <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                       that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                                    <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                       "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                                    <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                       resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                                       containing the link.</p>
                                 </div>
                              </details>
                           </div>
                        </section>

                        <section class="json-obj">

                              <div>
                                 <h8 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/include-subjects/props" class="toc8 head">props</h8>
                                 <p>An array of Property objects</p>
                                 <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                                 <div class="obj-desc">
                                    <div class="obj-matrix">
                                       <p class="obj-name">object Property</p>
                                       <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1 to ∞]</span></p>
                                       <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>
                                       <p class="path">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/include-subjects/props</p>
                                    </div>
                                    <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                                       qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                                       may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                                    <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                       <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                       <div class="remarks">
                                          <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                             OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                             or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                             and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                             an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                             lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                             consistency.</p>
                                          <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                             was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                             of the containing object.</p>
                                       </div>
                                    </details>
                                 </div>
                                 <div class="crosslink"><a href="../xml-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risk/origin/related-task/identified-subject/subject/include-subject/prop"><button class="schema-link">Switch to XML</button></a></div>
                              </div>
                           </div>
                           <p>See <a href="../json-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/include-subjects/props">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/include-subjects/props</a> in the object map.</p>

                                    organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                                    to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                                    can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                                    This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                                    an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                                    control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                                    uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                                    be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined

                                 <div class="obj-desc">

                                       <p>An object  member of array <code>props</code>.</p>

                                    </div>
                                    <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                                       qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                                       may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                                    <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                                       <summary>Remarks</summary>
                                       <div class="remarks">
                                          <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                             OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                             or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                             and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                             an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                             lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                             consistency.</p>
                                          <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                             was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                             of the containing object.</p>
                                       </div>
                                    </details>

                                    <h9 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/risks/origins/related-tasks/identified-subject/subjects/exclude-subjects/props/ns" class="toc9 head">ns</h9>Property NamespaceA namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different
                                    organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.Provides a means
                                    to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals
                                    can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property.
                                    This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on
                                    an organization-by-organization basis.An organization MUST use a URI that they have
                                    control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered
                                    uniform resource names (URN) namespace.When a ns is not provided, its value should
                                    be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined
                                    by the associated OSCAL model.
